awd_titl_txt: The Innovative Science Teaching Institute at Broward College: A College-Wide Effort to Improve Student Success, Learning, and Minority Achievement in Introductory Science Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a 2-year pilot of an institutional transformation program. The pilot will prepare 6 full-time STEM faculty and 10 part-time adjunct STEM instructors to shift to evidence-based teaching. The 6 faculty will redesign their courses during a 6-week summer professional development institute.  The new innovative approaches to teaching science courses will be disseminated to
10 adjunct faculty, also through the use of summer workshops. A particular strength of the project is its unique theory of change that includes the part-time adjunct instructors as a central element of its transformation plan. This college already provides professional development opportunities to adjunct instructors through the Adjunct Faculty Institute. Because many community colleges depend significantly on part-time adjunct instructors, this model is important to develop and investigate.  The participating faculty and instructors will be supported by learning assistants. The learning assistants will be drawn from former students who have already earned their degrees and are working as tutors at the Broward Academic Success Center. The work will be guided by an advisory committee that includes external experts.  

The project will be assessed to determine the impact of the course redesign effort on student success and student learning. The project will also investigate how changes in student behaviors and attitudes are related to improved learning and grades and how those relationships vary with the type of undergraduate student.

por.por_cntn:
In 2015, NSF Grant # 1524917 was awarded to Broward College.
This grant sought to improve STEM education and address low student success rates (less than 65%) in introductory science courses. The cornerstone of this NSF effort was the creation and implementation of a faculty-driven summer staff development teaching institute, the Innovative Science Teaching Institute (ISTI). ISTI was formed to teach active learning strategies and help faculty redesign STEM course offerings.

This grant consisted of two phases.
Phase I (2015-2017) consisted of 6 full time faculty members teaching Health Science and General education courses. Phase II (2018-2021) consisted of 4 part time and 1 full time faculty member teaching General education courses.

Phase II of the project faced extra challenges as all faculty moved from an in person learning environment to an online/remote learning environment due to Covid-19. Faculty had to adjust their active learning strategies and lessons to the online environment and must be commended for their adaptive abilities.

The following table highlights the original project goals and the progress made.

Table 1. Progress Across ISTI Goals.

Original ISTI Project Goals (2015)

2021 Updated Progress

Increase student success rates in general education & introductory science major courses.

Course success (C or Better) and A or B grade rates continue to reveal higher student performance for sections using active learning strategies.

Reduce a minority achievement gap in science.

Higher student success rates for sections using active learning remain in effect when controlling for gender and ethnicity

Increase student non-cognitive attitudes towards science.

Faculty reported increased student engagement in their courses after the implementation of active learning.

Better understand why changes in science pedagogy affect student outcomes.

In addition to increased student engagement, faculty using active learning strategies reported being more prepared to adapt/modify instruction strategies to match the pace of student learning.

Make a lasting impact on how science faculty view their role in the classroom.

Faculty fellows reported the workshop helped them gain confidence in their teaching ability and, as a result, felt they were better able to observe learning.


Results from the study suggests that the active learning workshops and course redesign that were implemented during Phase I and Phase II of the project did achieve the objective of increased student engagement and increased success rates. However, the data also suggests that this is most effective for General education courses such as Earth Science, Environmental Science and Biological Principals and not effective in Health Science courses such as Anatomy and Physiology, General Chemistry and Chemistry for Health Science . The reason being that for Health Science courses which have many learning objectives, it is a challenge for faculty to adequately cover all required course objectives in one term. The faculty who redesigned their Health Science courses reported struggling to cover all of the required content while also incorporating active learning strategies into their instruction. As a result, they felt that they were not able to give some topics the time needed for student comprehension. Overall grades did not improve and in the case of Chemistry for Health Sciences, slightly worse after course redesign.
General education courses tend to have more flexibility with how the content is presented and how course objectives are achieved. Also, General education courses tend to have less demanding material to comprehend as compared to Health Science courses. 

Phase II consisted of mostly selected adjunct faculty teaching General education courses. Faculty who completed Phase II of the ISTI active learning workshop reported a high degree of satisfaction with the workshop and believe their use of active learning strategies has contributed to improved student engagement, overall student mastery of learning objectives, and faculty-to-student engagement. Other significant feedback from adjunct faculty was their willingness to be part of the learning environment/network and receiving mentorship from full time faculty included in the Phase I study.

In summary, available data suggest active learning strategies and course redesign are positively impacting both student to faculty engagement and successful course completion. Course performance data and faculty feedback indicate the continued expansion of active learning strategies holds promise for increasing student learning outcomes and closing the minority student achievement gap in introductory STEM coursework. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/19/2021
Modified by: Henri Liauw A Pau
